reviews:
Very handy little light!
Does all you need it to do.
Word of caution! The light does have a button lock feature... however, if you have the lock in your pocket, it can easily bypass/unlock this feature and turn itself on... (it will heat up quickly depending on the brightness it's set to... you WILL feel it) ;)
Also, the paint/finish on the item scratches off very easy (had it only a few days on my keyring (with only 1 key on it) and it looks like it's a few months old already. So... if you want it as a good little flash light, you won't be disappointed; but if you want it to look good for a long time, don't carry it with you daily.

reviews:
I hesitated a bit before I bought this torch £62.95 is a lot of money and when you see and feel it, it doesn’t feel like £62.95.

Then you switch it on!

What a brilliant piece of EDC

Then it feels like £62.95, watch YouTube vids on this torch for all the tech spec and modes, the biggest selling point for this torch is that you can see how much run time you have for each mode for example 1 lumen = 70 hours which is the lowest setting, then 25 minutes in Turbo mode which is 1000 lumens, that will turn night into day, then you have all the other modes in between.

If you’re looking for a light powerful EDC torch this is worth considering, I think I paid the top end price wise and don’t feel cheated, but if you see it cheaper don’t hesitate to buy it.

reviews: Vorweg: Mit den kleineren Modellen von Nitecore war ich bisher ganz zufrieden. Daher sollte es dieses Mal ein teureres Modell für fast 70,- als Geschenk sein. Die erste Lieferung - auch direkt von amazon - musste ich bereits zurückschicken! Da der Karton doch recht verschmutzt und offensichtlich schon geöffnet war. Bei der zweiten Lieferung jetzt sah die Verpackung außen soweit OK aus, also habe ich das als Geschenk überreicht. Jetzt sehe ich nach dem Auspacken, dass das Display total verkratzt ist - s. Bild. Sogar mit einem recht deutlich Kratzer auf der rechten Seite. Laut Anleitung soll außerdem vor dem ersten Gebrauch "die Schutzfolie" auf dem OLE-Display entfernt werden. Da war nur leider gar keine Folie, ich war beim Öffnen der Verpackung dabei! Verkauft amazon hier jetzt jedesmal gebrauchte Ware oder Vorführmodelle??? Mir wurde das jedenfalls immer als "Neu" verkauft. Das ist extrem ärgerlich bei einem Geschenk, ich muss jetzt erst mal schauen, ob ich das überhaupt (zum zweiten Mal!) umtauschen kann. Nitecore sollte das mal prüfen. Entweder schicken sie selbst schon geöffnete/gebrauchte Ware ins Lager - oder das FBA (Fulfillment by amazon) funktioniert hier absolut nicht. So schnell kaufe ich jedenfalls keine Taschenlampe von Nitecore mehr. Nebenbei: Der Karton bei der teuren Taschenlampe ist ja ganz schick, aber dafür ist die Plastikverpackung dann halt innen drin. Für die Umwelt ist das jetzt auch nicht wirklich besser. Dann ist mir gleich außen eingeschweißt wie bei den Günstigeren lieber, da weiß man wenigstens sicher, dass das nicht schon geöffnet wurde.

reviews:
Your browser does not support HTML5 video.
 So I’ve been looking and collecting flashlights for the past few years (enthusiast but not quite there yet) and ran across this one. I was instantly hooked and let me tell you why.

First off, lets start with the light output itself, since a lot of people, including myself, just look at lumen output and think higher is better. While it is advertised and a max of 1000 lumens, this mode and only be achieved if you hold down the top button, as it will get hot fairly fast, and well a 1000 lumens being a 1000 lumens, you might not that much power for so long. It’s a nice way to safely use it, though I wish there was a way to constantly have it on. The next mode you can use is 200 lumens, which I recently used on night hike clipped on my hat which lit up more than enough at where I was looking. You also have the option to have it on without holding the top button, which is nice. It doesn’t get hot at this limit, and neither at 65, 15 and 1 lumen. I really like the moonlight option, which lets you see things late at night or early in the morning without causing too much of a disturbance, which is helpful for me when I look for things in the dark without waking up my roommate.

The user interface is designed in such a manner that it is easy for anyone that picks it up, and easy to learn and master. Out of the box, the light comes in Demo mode, which automatically shuts off the light after 30 seconds. It’s a nice mode to have if you don’t plan on having the light on constantly, such as checking items periodically, or carry it without having it on lockout mode, which we’ll get to shortly. The second mode which I use all the time, Daily, allows you to use the light with no limitations. Just as the name of the mode explains, it works well if you use it daily. Another great feature is a lockout mode, which basically means you have to press and hold a button to actually use the light. This is great if you use this as your everyday carry and don’t want to worry about the light burning a hole through your back pack or pants. The first lockout mode still allows you to go to turbo mode, which by the way you have to hold the top button to use. The second lockout mode blocks turbo mode and you have to manually unlock it to use. On top of all of this, an OLED screen is available to see what light output you have, voltage, time until the battery dies for every single light mode, lockout modes, and turbo mode. This is pretty unique to the lights ive seen so far, and I do have to say that I really do enjoy this feature on the light.

The build quality and design as overall quite great, but still leaves something to be worked on in future models. The main body is a hard plastic, which does make it lightweight, but I doubt it will survive medium drops, or will become scratched over time. The clip is an incredibly useful little feature, I use it on my hat just about every time I go hiking or at night. The lanyard hook on the rear actually does improve handling it in your hand, since it is quite small to begin with. The size of it is hard to tell from pictures, but it fits nicely in my pocket with no issues whatsoever. The charging port is a micro USB, which in 2018/9 is definitely outdated. Also the cover for the charging port can be easily pulled, which did happen to mine. I wish it was build just a tiddy bit better. The buttons are nice and clicky, but have way too play on them and wiggle a lot, even with a small amount of pressure.

There is certainly much more to work on in the next model, but overall I’m pretty happy for my new EDC light. I would highly recommend this for someone who needs an EDC light, but is looking for something powerful in a really small package.
product_name: Nitecore Tup 1000 Lumen RCHRGBL Keychain Flashlight Gray

reviews:
I'm generally a fan of the Nitecore keychain flashlights like the Tube, Tip, and Tini (I own them all). And this new TUP is a great concept. I love the informative display that indicates battery life and intensity. And the four preprogramed brightness levels are excellent - as is battery life. The build quality is very good too. The user interface is easy to use and understand. The form factor is too big for a keychain and it's awkwardly shaped, but it is small and light and bright and in most respects would make a great EDC light.

But the TUP is fatally flawed with significantly raised control buttons that take extremely low pressure to activate - which means there is no practical way to carry it without frequently activating it by accident. It does have a couple of lockout modes - one that locks out both buttons until you short click then long click the power button, and one that locks out the power button but that lets a long press of the intensity button activate the light at maximum intensity. But the full lockout still lights up the display any time you touch either button. And the other lockout mode is useless because a long press of the intensity button is easy to do by accident.

They need to recess the buttons, and make them significantly harder to press to make this a practical light.

This is a very disappointing product and I would not recommend nd it to anyone until its redesigned.

The beam is more flood making it great for an every day carry. Long lasting battery, ease of use, SUPER compact, great features and built in clip make this unbeatable in size/performance. You can't make a mistake buying this thing.

review_title: Not as good as the EC11, so sorry nitecore, swing and a miss. (Updated)
reviews:
My nitecore EC11 died a few months back, and when I went hunting for a replacement I came across this new flash light from nitecore. When I first got it, the first thing I noticed is that there were several little quirks that made this a lesser flashlight than my old EC11. One, you can't stand it on it's tail, a trick I used all the time with my EC11. Two, the battery is pemanent/rechargeable, you can't change batteries, and as the built in battery starts to fade, you are SOL. On my EC11, I could get rechargeable batteries for it, and when they faded, I would just replace them. Also, I could keep extras with me in my backpack or luggage, and if I needed more light than the battery in it had, it was 30 seconds to replace it and keep going. When this one runs low, you are done. Despite the fancier user interface, I find this one coming on in my pocket a lot more often (yes, I am FULLY familiar with the lock function, it's just a crappy design). With my EC11, if I was afraid it would accidentally turn on, I just twisted the tail cap a turn to prevent it from turning on. When I select the maximum brightness, I'm lucky to get 20 or 30 seconds before it turns off. The EC11 would usually go several minutes at max brightness and then just throttle back to the next lower level. The little screen that tells you what mode you are in is cute, but not really necessary. I'm looking for a replacement. I've got 6 or 8 nitecore flashlights (EA41s, TM06s's) I keep in various places, and have given several away as gifts to my friends (they love the EA41s). This is the first Nitecore I think they missed on.

I've changed my rating on this to 0 stars. Despite using both of the safety lockouts on this, it turned on in my jacket pocket, and melted the front lens. The protective circuit that was supposed to prevent overheating obviously failed miserably.

review_title: Great little light, but one flaw
reviews:
This is an amazing little light that fits in your keychain (although a little bulky compared to the TUP2). The 1000 lumens is nothing short of extraordinary for the size of this light. The chargeable port is fantastic and easily accessible and while using during the more 60 and 200 lumen modes, it holds a pretty good service time.

My one big issue which did cause me to return the item in exchange for a second TUP2 is the power button. While it has a anti-accidental on feature of having to hold the button for 3 seconds to turn on (except for the 1000 lumen bypass), it's not enough to prevent a pocket activation. While 60 to 200 lumen won't be much of an issue, if this thing fires up for an extended time at 1000 lumen it could light your butt on fire (maybe). Either way, it'll drain the battery without you knowing and for when you truly need it.
The TUP 2 however has a guard over the power button, making accidental pressing in your pocket by just sitting incorrectly almost impossible. The TUP 2 while not as bright nor have as long of a battery life, serves as good for a keychain light (700 max lumen).

reviews:
I initially bought this because of the shape and the orientation of the 'clip'. I'd planned to build a mount so that I could use it on a machine tool in my shop during a particular operation where I needed more light and can't have any wires in the way. I'm an admitted Nitecore fanboy, and have always been happy with their products and value.

After using it for that particular job, I added it to the pile of stuff I carry around in my pockets all day long. It's light, small, powerful, and works well. The dual-lockout functions are kinda weird and difficult to operate sometimes, as well as the demo/daily modes. Read the manual and practice the button hold sequence before you actually need light. It's not difficult but can be frustrating when your hands are full, you can't see, and can't get the flashlight to turn on because it's locked. The lock mode is necessary though as the light turns on very easily by bumping into other objects in your pockets.

review_title: Very nice palm size light with smart screen
reviews: I am a flashlight fan and have too many to list from Surefire and Fenix to NiteCore, Nebo and several others but this one has become a recent favorite with a few minor annoyances. Ok the display and runtime are the best features (and I ended up getting a FENIX UC52 because I love the OLED feature so much!) but some minor issues with the design and ergonomics as other reviewers have mentioned- not able to tail stand, no magnet and the loop needs to be bigger like the Nitecore THUMB which this is replacing due to the THUMB’s short battery life. Having a larger attachment point eliminates the need for the mini biner clip which dangles when its clipped to a hat brim and yes you could put it on top of the hat but the angle is better below. This one beats the TIP2 because of it’s display and a better more robust metal clip but TIP2 might be worth checking out if the magnet feature is important to you. The body shape and size is a bit awkward- too big for a keychain and too squared and thick for a comfortable pocket carry (unless its winter and your wearing a coat with larger pockets). While charging the buttons blink blue and then remains solid and I wonder how much wasted battery drain this causes if charging from a battery pack. Memorizing the lock, lockout 1 and 2 is tedious and frustrating and could be eliminated with recessed buttons. I am a fan of tactical tail cap switches that unfortunately this one also lacks but having a switch for turbo when you need it fast and without fiddling would be a good idea. The power remaining and battery status indicator is really the best thing going for this light. It has a good assortment of brightness levels from very dim to very bright however its max brightness is momentary and you would benefit from using a bigger light than this one if you want pure lumen output and runtime at max. The power port has a slight recess to it if you are using magnetic usb chargers like I do so this is one works well with that slight modification.

reviews:

 I use this light multiple times every day for work for the past 5-6 weeks and it's perfect for what I do. I use it to walk down the driveway at night and it lights it up like it's daytime. Never had a functionality issue with it. The battery life is awesome for such a tiny light, on average I use it for two days at a time in between charges. It's so small I've started to carry this flashlight wherever I go. Much better than those cheapo pen lights the EDC people use. My one complaint would be the quality of the finish. It's very prone to scratches and the plastic chrome pieces will lose all its chrome as most of mine is already gone (the chrome on the buttons seem to be holding up much better than the trim pieces). The functionality of the light has not changed at all. If you want to take that teeny tiny keyring out of the bottom of it like I did, you gotta use a pair of dikes to cut it out.

reviews:
It's a bit big for a Keychain light, but it is an easy light to carry in the coin pocket of your Levi's using its attached metal clip.
I love the gray color of the flashlight with its contrasting silver colored buttons and trim on the sides. The OLED display is covered with a protective film that isn't obvious at first, but needs to be removed. Otherwise, you might think, as I did, that the display is scratched or cloudy.
The display shows your light level, lumens, remaing hours of use on that level, voltage, which mode you are in, etc. The light output and throw is amazing for a light of its size. The tint of the light is neutral for the most part, but on lower brightness levels it may take on a hint of green to the white. The lowest mode is supposed to be 1 lumens, but on mine I would guess it is a bit higher. That might be my only small disappointment with this light.
However, at the other extreme, the Turbo mode seems to be brighter than claimed 1000 lumens, even though the light would get too hot, if you were to use this mode more than intermittently. (In order to protect your hand and this little flashlight, Nitecore only allows an intermittent Turbo).

reviews: Love this little light and can only think of a few things that I would like to see changed. First would be that I would like to have the turbo setting one of the constant on levels instead of only while holding the mode button. Second thing is I would like like to not have the key ring loop on the bottom because it eliminates the possibility of tail standing the light on a flat surface. Ok one more thing is to have the option to get a tint that is a little more natural white instead of a cool white which is a slightly bluish or even something warmer with a yellowish beam. Otherwise I find this thing amazing for a little pocket/ keychain sized light and can’t wait to play some more with it tonight.

review_title: Smaller than likely think, cool spin on the flashlight
reviews:
Product even smaller than expected, though still a tad too large for true keychain carry for me. Given the output, that’s okay with me.

Beam is a nice white temperature and very much a flood, though throw is decent at the higher lumen settings. Turbo, the 1000 lumen level, is bright enough to be used in a defensive capacity or flash at a bad driver during a night walk. It’s the perfect night dog walking/jogging light since it’s so light, bright, and user interface allows for access to the 1000 lumens instantly.

My only issue is the charging port cover. It feels rather flimsy when moved to charge the light, but it does stay in place nicely. It’s still fully intact after three months use, I just anticipate it’ll be the weak point in the long term.

It’s a cool light and brings some different ideas, such as the LCD screen, to the flashlight. I also like the plastic housing on this light as opposed to a much heavier, colder metal body.

reviews: The brightest setting (1000lm at 25sec burst at a time) of this minuscule flashlight is comparable to modern cars' projector headlights. And, in normal use.. 3h at 200lm, over 9h at 65lm, almost 19h at 15lm, and over 71h at lm. Wow! This is part of my EDC gear, and it's perfect for versatility. 1lm is excellent for extra dim light such as when waking up in unfamiliar surroundings while on travel, or at a movie theater. Meanwhile, 200lm is very sufficient for "normal flashlight use" while the 1000lm burst is great as an outdoor searchlight. Highly recommended!
product_name: Nitecore Tup 1000 Lumen RCHRGBL Keychain Flashlight Gray

reviews: While to me it was a little pricey when I ordered it, I was very happy once I received it. This chunky little light feels great in your hand. Cool mini LED display shows all kinds of info like batt life in hours, modes, etc. This is great for lighting up dark rooms, basements, and your backyard. I have annoyed my neighbors multiple times by shining this around on turbo mode outside my house. Would recommend. Handy mini USB charging. Pocket clip is very sturdy. Great little light.

reviews: I've had this for several months now and like using it. The different light levels works very well and the battery life is great. review_title: Read the included instructions. There is nothing ambiguous about them.
reviews:
I own several “specialty” lights from well known manufacturers.
This Nitecore Tup is well made and functions as advertised.
The common theme I see time after time that is critical of a quality or function issue is one I would expect from those folks that toss the instructions out with the packaging when they get the product.
The comments are generally born of ignorance.
I actually saw a question answered by someone that suggested the 1 lumen run time for this light was 80 minutes......
Absolutely incredible....!....It is well over 70.....HOURS !!!
Very good light. Fair price.....just READ the spec’s AND the instructions.
